text: What's your most underrated Claude Code trick?
ultrayolo

exporting my raw session logs to obsidian and also making a summary session log that updates in real time

now both me and claude can know exactly what we did and when in both short and verbose ways
custom skills. wrote one with my codebase patterns and now every new session already knows the architecture. no more re-explaining context

ask claude to document everything in an .MD that follows strict guidelines for naming and file content structure. 

use each file as context for human + claude, and then use each as bridge to next working session.

Not a trick, but I’ll architect an entire app, database, UI, down to the route in Claude desktop. Then I use Claude desktop to create optimized prompts per Claude code session. So I end up with 12-16 prompts that inherit and depend on the previous ones expected output to succeed.

run `brew install douglance/tap/devsql`  

then ask claude "Use devql and figure out what were my most successful prompts? which prompts should i turn into commands?"

This new auto compaction thing with a good roadmap plan mode, you can work like 4hs on same session, it’s just wild.

Upload your entire codebase to Projects so Claude actually understands your file structure and conventions instead of hallucinating imports that don't exist. Also, being super specific about what NOT to change saves way more time than vague prompts about what you want.

Never using a tool for something that prompting vanilla Claude Code can do

I never have to wonder if a capability is coming from Claude or the tool

It takes more prompts at first, but makes discovering higher order prompts a part of every repetition
for non-trivial things: "ask me as many clarifying questions as you need before getting started"

Dream come true 

Waking life.
Don't let it go wild. Be the driver and keep Claude on a leash. So much wasted time by letting go and have Claude go in circles fixing one bug but spawning three new ones.

Plugins allow me to create both workflows and both static and dynamic sub-agents, eliminating the need for a framework. Testing and improvement are straightforward, relying mostly on human language. However, I would appreciate the ability to "branch" or "fork" the main agent
“trust your gut”
using Claude Code to build macOS automations.. shortcuts for the workflow, AppleScript for the glue, bash for the heavy lifting.

i also like to make my agents compete over who’s solution is best.  then merge the best of both.

This took me way too long to realize: using the /compact command isn't just for cleaning up. It actually resets the context window so Claude doesn't get "hallucination fog" during long sessions.

I keep getting asked: What IDE do you use?
My response: We don't need IDE's. 

CC FTW!

Claude in the Cloud from iPhone

1. Get a VPS for $6/mo
2. Login & Install Claude
3. Use Termius from iPhone to SSH in

You now have your own Claude in the Cloud to code on the go, push, deploy, build agents - you don’t need vibe coding apps, you got Claude!

Paste the error, don't explain it.
Claude reads stack traces better than your interpretation.

I was using skills before they were a thing. 

/backend, /frontend, /fullstack and a few variants each. Each loading necessary context via @ references to relevant files. 

Just enough context for the specific task at hand. 

Still using them.
disable the auto compact

3 steps:
- I create the prompt.
- I rewrite it and convert it to MARKDOWN file with Sonnet.
- I give it to Opus 4.5 for execution 

It works like a charm

Simply compacting on your own terms, instead of reaching auto-compact trigger point. This has improved my results significantly. 
The second biggest improvement came from asking Claude to review and ask me clarifying questions. It doesn’t do it by itself every time so better ask.
"ask me clarifying questions about the task", "when using Y technology, what's the biggest footgun"

I created a /follow-up command that I use when context window is more that 70% full. In understands the context and creates a follow-up self-contained prompt for whatever next step I want to perform. It usually tells briefly what has been done and shows files and areas of code
getting out the way..
"Please verify your final answer with the Reexpress tool."
Give Claude a cli tool to convert svgs to pngs so it can view them and iterate

The artifacts window. most people dont realize you can run entire projects in there before dropping them into your actual codebase. its basically a sandbox that counts towards your context but doesnt pollute your working directory. saves a lot of back and forth.
Because Honestly tired of getting flickering screen and I feel like the rate limits have been halved rather than 2x'ed
At the end of every prompt add "before giving your final answer, go back and be better"

Most underrated trick with Claude Code is to thoroughly read its outputs and de-slop the code & docs. 

Second most underrated trick is to have it manage issues and PRs using the gh CLI, and track progression in a GitHub Project board.

Now that I think about it, my most valuable trick is leveraging Claude Code deeper than just the app layer. It helps me with hardware issues, driver issues, and anything else on my PC. It has its hands on EVERYTHING.

Not a trick per se, but Claude in Chrome is super underrated as a browser agent. Comet's agent is faster but Claude in Chrome is more accurate and capable.

using git worktrees with claude
That way I have an Orchestrator agent on my master branch and then my agent checks on what all happens in different branches in different worktrees. The parallelization factor has increased by a lot just because of using Git worktrees

Give CC an alternative stopping point if it can't get something to work. Keeps it from churning on a problem or dithering between two non-working solutions.

I run my home server with two agents. One for server infra and one for app/tool developments. The main md file makes the division of labor very clear. No agent does the work of another. So much so that if I ask the infra agent for app-related tasks, it’d apologize and delegate it
"In any point of the way, think, what would a Senior Dev do in that case"
So I basically say ill tip her 2000 dollars, it does well.

When building interfaces, create a folder with all the screenshots and references. When you start to work on that, provide Claude Code default references. That way, you don't need to have a bunch of screenshots around your desktop or computer, and you can just centralize

When you are struggling with Claude code to do some tasks, take time and ask the model where you are failing to provide the right prompt to the model. The model is very smart, and they will provide you with guidance on how you can provide better prompts.

After writing an initial plan, I clear context and ask it to quiz me until we've got alignment on the plan. This helps get rid of a lot of weird ai slop code that would have otherwise been generated and reduces the size and coverage of your initial prompt.

Running Claude Code in docker so it has no access to my tokens/configs/ssh keys

Basically 
docker run --rm -it -v "$pwd/proj-dir:/w" -w /w claude claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

manual "planning mode":
- "this is what I want: now make a detailed make a plan in MD"
- review and refine plan
- "make iterative implementation plan. implement each step and let me test afterwards"

One underrated trick: using Claude Code for context aware refactoring. Feed it a messy function or module, ask it to rewrite with your style + constraints, and it often produces cleaner, more maintainable code than basic autocomplete.
